awards.title: Participant Innovation Games: Living Lab Brabant
awards.description: For the economics and innovation department of the province of Noord-Brabant I spent t a week  brainstorming on the complex issue of robotisation in the (elderly) care sector, together with a group of young professionals .

awards.title: Participant Trainingsweekend Nederlandse Klimaatbeweging
awards.description: Milieudefensie, Greenpeace, de Stroomversnellers and other green organisations regularly host a weekend for the Dutch climate movement, for the people who are the forefront of the transition to a fossil free, sustainable and just society. I have participated in four weekends in which I broadened my network and gained relevant skills and contributed to the further development of the green movement in the Netherlands.

awards.title: Participant Energy Innovation Talks
awards.description: The Energy innovation talks are an initiative of Sustainable Motion and the SER (social-economic council) to offer young professionals a several trainings and public speaking opportunities to become the ambassadors of the clean energy transition.

awards.title: NGO-Delegate at COP21
awards.description:
As a delegate for CapGlobalCarbon I attended the COP 21 climate conference and presented on an official UNFCCC side event called "Climate Justice: Coal and Human Rights in the South, Community Choice Energy, Global Carbon Pricing"
Affected communities are often forgotten in high-level talks on climate action. We highlight human rights impacts by the coal sector in the South, Community Choice Energy to speed a transition to renewables, and establish a Global Climate Trust to “CapGlobalCarbon” and return funds to people.
Speakers: Shawn Marshall (LEAN Energy US), Dawn Weisz (Marin Clean Energy, USA); Krizna Gomez (Dejusticia, Colombia), Gregory Regaignon (Business and Human Rights Resource Centre, USA); Mike Sandler (Carbon Share USA), Erik-Jan van Oosten (FEASTA Netherlands), Caroline Whyte (FEASTA France)

awards.title: Young talent at EP-NUFFIC Erasme-Decartes conference on Green growth and Sustainability transitions
awards.description: I participated in the annual French-Dutch collaboration brainstorm, this year themed "green growth and sustainable transitions", as one of the 30 Young Talents. After the first day I was selected to present my views on economic growth on the main stage of the Erasme Decartes conference. Along with the Dutch and French ambassador I have written an introduction to the resulting publication.

awards.title: Participant Sustainability Challenge
awards.description: Together with recent graduates from Delft and Utrecht I researched sustainable lightning options at train stations for ProRail.

organizations.name: Feasta, The Foundation for the Economics of Sustainability

projects.title: Self Sufficiency Summer School at Strohplatz
projects.description: What is it like to live off-grid and self-sufficient? For a group of 18 Wageningen University students I organized a weekend long excursion to Strohplatz, a pioneer in sustainable living in the rural German Eiffel to experience and study the  effects of being off-grid.

projects.title: Organic vs. Intensive Agriculture: The Facts
projects.description: RUW Foundation visited organic farm the Hooilanden on the 6th of June. I supported my colleagues Roos Akkerman and Maria-Franca in the preparation and execution of the excursion and panel debate. The panel consisted of Bert Rijk, from Plant Production Systems (WUR), Bernadette Backers, from Organic Shop de Kardoen in Bennekom, Ellen Hartman, professor Nutrition and Disease (WUR), Maria-Franca Dekkers and Houkje Adema. The last two are students from the honours-program who wrote in a team of five students the book: “A closer look into organic statements (Biologische stellingen onder de loep)”. We discussed six statements from this book, with plenty of opportunity for the audience to ask their questions, place comments, and even sometimes act as the expert.

projects.title: A Big Day Full of Tiny Houses
projects.description: On Saturday the 13th of May I co-organised a Tiny House day. This included a keynote by Marjolein Jonker, first Tiny-house inhabitant of the Netherlands, a tour to two tiny houses and a workshop tiny-house design.

contributors.headline: Redacteur Natuur en Omgeving bij Groen Kennisnet

projects.title: Grassroots Science: Education
projects.description: Grassroots Science is an annual series of events about a topic linked to sustainability, from a local, practice-based approach. This year Otherwise and RUW foundation organised this series about academic education at the WUR. We explored different methods of teaching in five different events. These events are linked in the sense that the first 4 events are examples of empowering, non-conventional education methods, and that in the 5th event the possibilities of integrating these more involved forms of education into the Wageningen curriculum are explored with an expert panel. My involvement was coordination, promotion, poster design, photography, facilitation and a presention of our results at the final debate.

projects.title: Social Sustainability: masterclass with Paul Hendriksen
projects.description: The interesting connections between the societal and environmental aspects of sustainability were explained by our keynote guest speaker Paul Hendriksen during the WEPtalks on the 10th and 24th of January. Paul, chairman of the Transition Towns network in the Netherlands, has great knowledge on the way sustainability is fused in the social connections people have with one another.  I Organised two events with Paul: a lecture and a workshop.

contributors.headline: Redacteur Natuur en Omgeving bij Groen Kennisnet
Open to new opportunities. Experience in movement building and strategic campaigning. Project- and wastemanagement. Spokesperson.

projects.title: Food4All Film Festival
projects.description: On the final evening of the Food4All Film Festival I screened the award winning documentary "Just Eat It" by Grant Baldwin and Jenny Rustemeyer at Movie W. This is a documentary about food waste that addresses the issue from both a birds-eye perspective by looking at the food chain and a personal perspective where we follow Jen and Grant in their challenge to only consume food waste for 6 months. Before the movie I gave an introduction talk about food waste in a local context (such as the Foodsharing Wageningen Platform) and presented two books about cooking with food waste to browse through during the break. The movie was followed by a 20 minute conversation about our food waste which I facilitated. The 40 to 45 people that attended this screening felt that they needed to change their behavior and saw food waste not just as an inefficiency but as an ethical issue. Practical advice on how to ask shop keepers for food waste was exchanged, as well as an academic discussion on the role of population in food scarcity was held. Other feedback included remarks on the role of Wageningen University and its focus on the production of food in its research and education, underplaying the importance of the food waste crisis. The argument was made that a cultural shift towards a more sustainable society has to include how we treat and consume our food.

contributors.headline: Redacteur Natuur en Omgeving bij Groen Kennisnet
Coordinator at Rural Wageningen Foundation (RUW)

projects.title: Standing Rock: Dakota Access Pipeline Information Meeting
projects.description:
In the end of 2016 there was an uprising in the United States over the construction of the Dakota Access Pipeline. A group of Native American tribes, environmentalists and journalists aims to protect the sacred burial grounds, protect their water and to uphold their rights to the land as granted in 1868. What started as a conflict between a company and a group of concerned citizens has over the course of a few months escalated into an armed siege facing the Standing Rock community. 
On Thursday 3 November RUW Foundation and OtherWise Wageningen hosted an information meeting about this situation, followed by a Skype session with the people at the front line. Our keynote Chihiro Geuzebroek, an expert on indigenous culture and history in the context of environmentalism, provided us with context to understand this situation. She first explored the narratives of indigenous rights, climate justice and colonialism. 
A recurring theme in her talk was genocide. Both in the literal sense where colonists were rewarded for killing Indians during the ‘wild wild west’ era, but also the cultural genocide taking Native American children and putting them in special schools. A remarkable example of genocide was the killing of the bison, the main source of food for many Native Americans. Chihiro described this as a  purposeful act of ecocide with the aim of causing genocide. The rise of capitalism was a turning point when it comes to how Native Americans were valued. From being seen as savages by the colonists, they were now seen as a cheap source of labor. The combination of systemic racism and capitalism resulted in far-reaching efforts to make Native Americans part of the lowest working class.  Today, many the Native Americans see the violent attempts to remove them from their ancestral land in the context of colonisation. The battle they are fighting to keep their land is no different to them from when their ancestors fought to defend this land from invading armies.

contributors.headline: Redacteur Natuur en Omgeving bij Groen Kennisnet
Tuinder en terreinbeheerder Aardewerk- de Stegge
Climate justice activist, singersongwriter, teacher, speaker, trainer

projects.title: Regreening weekend
projects.description:
On the 9th, 10th and 11th of September Wageningen's first Re-Greening weekend took place. This is a collaborative introduction to the many green initiatives, places and people of Wageningen. Key organisers were Wageningen Environmental Platform, Fossil Free Wageningen and DWARS. RUW Foundation took on the role of promotion by creating and distributing the greenactive flyer and hosted the two capacity-building and community mapping sessions.
On Saturday the 10th I introduced the green active network to the new students of the Wageningen University and provided an overview of the current state of activities in Wageningen. After giving 8 different organisations 3 minutes to pitch what their initiative does, needs and wants a speed-date session between the new students was hosted. Several organisations have found interested people for their student boards and gained volunteers during this afternoon.
On Sunday the 11th of September I organised a workshop in which green and ambitious plans for the next academic year were made at Thuis Wageningen. The participants of the Re-greening weekend and representatives of the green organisations all hosted an "open space"  in which they were to discuss their ideas for the next academic year. In 4 rounds of open spaces many alliances were formed between people, places and organisations, several ideas for upcoming activities were created and solutions for unsustainable situations were discussed.
These sessions formed the reflective part of the weekend and the outcomes from both sessions are collected in a harvest document. The re-greening weekend was well received by both the participants and the organisers and it is intended to make this an annual recurring event that is up to par with the introduction weekends organised by the student associations.

projects.title: Degrowth Conference Relocalised
projects.description: A new economic paradigm called Degrowth is emerging. Through more sharing, more free time, less stuff and new forms of collaborating we can all live an enjoyable and meaningful life within planetary boundaries. In Budapest a 5 day Degrowth conference will take place from 30 August until 3 September. RUW Foundation re-localised this conference in Wageningen. As a co-location of the conference a live video connection with the main event was established through which we followed and contributed to the debate.

projects.title: Debate: Round Table on Sustainable Palm Oil
projects.description:
What is sustainable palm oil? Can palm oil production be sustainable? How successful is the cooperation of NGO's and multinationals on the issue of palm oil? We hosted an interactive discussion on the roundtable on sustainable palm oil (RSPO) with various experts to discuss this issue. 
The panel discussion on the state of affairs of the RSPO was attended by 40 people, of which a large portion indonesian students as that country is the world’s main producer of palm oil. With speakers from Taskforce Duurzame Palmolie, Solidaridad and the WUR (Maja Slingerland, Michiel Köhne and Sakti Hutabaret) we ensured that we covered all sides from the palm oil debate. My role was coordinating and promoting the event.

contributors.headline: Redacteur Natuur en Omgeving bij Groen Kennisnet

projects.title: SPARK! Lecture Kris de Decker: Low-tech Solutions for a Sustainable Society
projects.description: On my invitation, Kris de Decker presented a thought-provoking SPARK! lecture on the role of technology and innovation for sustainability for Climate-KIC. His excellent work on low-tech alternatives made him a key figure in the bottom-up sustainability movement. During this event Kris shared his insights in sustainable technologies and he highlighted the immense business opportunities he sees for low-tech solutions. I organised the event, made the announcement poster and was responsible for the communication.

projects.title: Towards climate safety and justice: briefing and discussion about CapGlobalCarbon
projects.description:
Role: Guestspeaker and co-organiser at cultivate's 2 day conference "transition just safe climate" in Ireland. 
On 8 and 9 June I presented the CapGlobalCarbon project to the Irish environmental movement. The second day I gave a more detailed presentation at a full-day brainstorm event with key actors in the field of climate change. Other presenters include Lorna Gold, Anne B Ryan and Duncan Steward.

projects.title: Documentary screening of Disobedience with Fossil Free Wageningen
projects.description: Role: organiser and promotion. Together with Fossil Free Wageningen I organised two documentary screenings of 350.org's "Disobedience: Courage to break free" at the Wageningen University for students and staff. The screenings were followed by debates about divestment and civil disobedience with two students that attended the Ende Galende protest.

projects.title: Refugees in Wageningen – Spotlight on experiences: Storytelling and panel discussion
projects.description: Role: co-organiser. Stichting OtherWise, RUW Foundation, Amnesty Students Wageningen, and Stichting Vluchteling Onder Dak organised an event on the 2nd March aims to bring together citizens, students of Wageningen, experts, political activists and refugee voices to discuss and share opinions from a human rights, law and policy perspective.The event will started with storytelling by two activist refugees who shared their experiences with the audience. This was followed by an expert panel discussion.

projects.title: Climate Change in Court | Discussing the Urgenda climate case: the role of law in climate policy
projects.description: Role: organiser and initiator. On the 26th of November the RUW foundation organised, together with Green Office Wageningen and the Law and Governance Group, a panel debate on the role of law and legal action in addressing climate change. After the remarkable Urgenda Climate Case ruling there is much debate in the legal community on the potential of the law in protecting the climate.

projects.title: Why Price Nature? The role of economics in the protection of nature
projects.description: Should we value eco-system services in terms of money? Does a price tag on nature help to protect it or to destroy it? There is a fundamental disagreement between scientists in the area of nature protection on the monetization of nature. Stichting RUW and Green Office hosted a debate as an opening of the Seriously Sustainable Week between two experts from our university: Dr. Dolf De Groot, Associate Professor in Integrated Ecosystem Assessment & Management with the Environmental Systems Analysis Group and Prof. Dr. Bram Büscher, Chair of the Sociology of Development and Change Group.This debate was facilitated by Dr. Ir. Martijn Duineveld, Assistant Professor at the Cultural Geography Chair Group.

projects.description: Role: Tour guide, promotion and organiser. ”Tour de Wageningen’ is Stichting RUW’s annual cycling tour to show you the surroundings of Wageningen and to introduce you to interesting, sustainable and high quality projects and shops. The excursion includes a guided tour through the famous nature area,” De Blauwe Kamer” and the mill market festival. This tour was guided and organised by Erik-Jan.

projects.title: “Resource Revolution” Buitex to Berlin and Leipzig
projects.description: Stichting RUW organized an 8 day excursion to Berlin and Leipzig for 25 students in collaboration with the RSO Group. The program contained visits ranging from aquaphonics systems to repair cafés and included lectures from Cradle to Cradle and a former member of parliament for the German Green Party. The lively debates between the participants were induced by the paradigm shifting concepts encountered during the trip, such as the Circular Economy, Degrowth and Upcycling.

projects.title: Global ways to CO2 reduction
projects.description: Role: facilitator and host. RUW Foundation organised, together with the Law and Governance group, an academic debate on the nexus between law, economy and climate policy with renowned experts on climate change solutions and their barriers. We zoomed in on one of the most important puzzles for international governance to solve: the global reduction of CO2.

profile_positions.title: Stockroom Manager and Order Picker

volunteer_experiences.description: CapGlobalCarbon addresses an absolutely vital issue: the urgent need to start progressively reducing total global emissions from the use of fossil fuels. The idea is to impose an ‘upstream cap’: an annually reducing limitation on the total amount of coal, oil and gas that can be introduced onto the market anywhere in the world. The cap is implemented by a global licence system. A limited number of licences are issued each year, these are auctioned and governments ban the introduction of fuels not covered by a licence.

I support the local Fossil Free campaign. I've contributed by organizing movie screenings,  printing flyers and posters, writing, social media promotion and attending the team meetings. I intend to help this activist student group at least once a month.
